articles.headline: President’s Growing Trade Gap: A Gulf Between Talk and Action
articles.snippet: The president said two new executive orders would “set the stage for a great revival of American manufacturing,” but they probably won’t make much difference.
articles.abstract: The president said two new executive orders would “set the stage for a great revival of American manufacturing,” but they probably won’t make much difference.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Increasingly, when it comes to foreign trade, the Trump administration is talking loudly and brandishing a small stick.

articles.headline: Foreigners Have Long Mined Indonesia, but Now There’s an Outcry
articles.snippet: Protesters are pressing the government to push back against Freeport-McMoRan, a U.S. mining giant, and to regain control of natural resources.
articles.abstract: Protesters are pressing the government to push back against Freeport-McMoRan, a U.S. mining giant, and to regain control of natural resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Crowned with spiky feathered headdresses and daubed with face paint, scores of protesters gathered outside the Jakarta offices of an American mining giant last week, chanting, waving signs and throwing uncertainty into global commodities markets.

articles.headline: A Real Estate Boom, Powered by Pot
articles.snippet: The legalization of marijuana is upending the market for warehouses and retail stores, as companies pay a premium for places to grow and sell it.
articles.abstract: The legalization of marijuana is upending the market for warehouses and retail stores, as companies pay a premium for places to grow and sell it.
articles.lead_paragraph: QUINCY, Mass. — At the edge of an industrial park in this suburb south of Boston, past a used-car auction lot and a defunct cheese factory, is an unmarked warehouse bristling with security cameras and bustling with activity. Until recently, the cinder-block structure was home to a wholesale florist, a granite cutter and a screen printer. Today, it is home to just one tenant: a medical marijuana operation called Ermont.

articles.headline: Bill O’Reilly Thrives at Fox News, Even as Harassment Settlements Add Up
articles.snippet: About $13 million has been paid out over the years to address complaints from women about Mr. O’Reilly’s behavior. He denies the claims have merit.
articles.abstract: About $13 million has been paid out over the years to address complaints from women about Mr. O’Reilly’s behavior. He denies the claims have merit.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades, Bill O’Reilly has been Fox News’s top asset, building the No. 1 program in cable news for a network that has pulled in billions of dollars in revenues for its parent company, 21st Century Fox.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: A Pentagon Test for Boeing’s Mr. Fix-It
articles.snippet: Patrick M. Shanahan brings a reputation as an aerospace troubleshooter to his expected nomination for the No. 2 defense job, which others found too big to handle.
articles.abstract: Patrick M. Shanahan brings a reputation as an aerospace troubleshooter to his expected nomination for the No. 2 defense job, which others found too big to handle.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2007, Boeing’s chief executive, W. James McNerney Jr., put out an S O S call to the head of the company’s military business. Boeing had bet its future on a revolutionary passenger jet, the 787 Dreamliner, and the project was imperiled by delays and cost overruns.

articles.headline: Conservative Split Over Import Tax Imperils Trump’s Overhaul
articles.snippet: A proposed “border adjustment” tax is meeting furious opposition, threatening to jeopardize yet another signature legislative initiative.
articles.abstract: A proposed “border adjustment” tax is meeting furious opposition, threatening to jeopardize yet another signature legislative initiative.
articles.lead_paragraph: One conservative group produced colorful flow charts warning millennials that a “border adjustment” tax proposed by Speaker Paul D. Ryan would raise prices on “the Jose Cuervo tequila that’s in your happy hour margarita.”
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Tribes That Live Off Coal Hold Tight to Trump’s Promises
articles.snippet: The Crow of Montana are among several Indian nations looking to the president’s pledges to end Obama-era coal rules or approve new oil and gas wells.
articles.abstract: The Crow of Montana are among several Indian nations looking to the president’s pledges to end Obama-era coal rules or approve new oil and gas wells.
articles.lead_paragraph: CROW AGENCY, Mont. — The pale yellow halls of the Crow government building here are nearly empty these days, with 1,000 of this tribe’s 1,300 employees recently laid off.

articles.headline: Trump Couple, Now White House Employees, Can’t Escape Conflict Laws
articles.snippet: Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump are walking on perilous legal and ethical ground, according to several prominent experts on the subject.
articles.abstract: Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump are walking on perilous legal and ethical ground, according to several prominent experts on the subject.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The husband-and-wife team of Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump, now both senior federal government officials, has been alongside President Trump as the White House has hosted dozens of chief executives and a handful of world leaders in recent weeks.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: China Learns How to Get Trump’s Ear: Through Jared Kushner
articles.snippet: Mr. Kushner’s role reflects the highly personal and bluntly transactional relationship between the United States and China, a risky strategy, experts say.
articles.abstract: Mr. Kushner’s role reflects the highly personal and bluntly transactional relationship between the United States and China, a risky strategy, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump welcomes President Xi Jinping of China to his palm-fringed Florida club for two days of meetings on Thursday, the studied informality of the gathering will bear the handiwork of two people: China’s ambassador to Washington and Mr. Trump’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner.

articles.headline: The Ad Feels a Bit Like Oscar Bait, but It’s Trying to Sell You an iPhone
articles.snippet: Artists and brands are collaborating on advertisements that move away from mere product placement, a practice so common that the Tribeca Film Festival has an award for it.
articles.abstract: Artists and brands are collaborating on advertisements that move away from mere product placement, a practice so common that the Tribeca Film Festival has an award for it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Carrie Brownstein, the actress known for the series “Portlandia,” wrote and directed a short film last fall that pokes fun at the exaggerated comments people post under pictures of celebrities on social media, showing what would happen if reverential remarks like “Mom” or “marry me” played out in the real world.

articles.headline: 2 Survivors of Canada’s First Quintuplet Clan Reluctantly Re-emerge
articles.snippet: Separated from their family and exhibited in a human zoo during the 1930s, the last sisters face a new indignity: the sale of their childhood home.
articles.abstract: Separated from their family and exhibited in a human zoo during the 1930s, the last sisters face a new indignity: the sale of their childhood home.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH BAY, Ontario — The tiny log house alongside the Trans-Canada Highway is easy to miss among the strip malls, fast-food outlets and car dealers. But 83 years ago, it was the eye of a publicity maelstrom because of a one-in-a-billion event: the birth of five identical baby girls.

articles.headline: Mexico Ready to Play the Corn Card in Trade Talks
articles.snippet: Much of the corn Mexico consumes comes from the United States, potentially making it a useful lever in negotiations over Nafta.
articles.abstract: Much of the corn Mexico consumes comes from the United States, potentially making it a useful lever in negotiations over Nafta.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — From the hundreds of millions of tortillas consumed every year to the countless tons of corn-enriched feed that fattens livestock and poultry, corn is perhaps Mexico’s most important agricultural commodity, one at the center of its life and culture.

articles.headline: Dyson Is the Apple of Appliances (and Just as Secretive)
articles.snippet: With an eye for both design and engineering, this British consumer electronics company is aiming for — and winning — the high end of the market.
articles.abstract: With an eye for both design and engineering, this British consumer electronics company is aiming for — and winning — the high end of the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: MALMESBURY, England — When Michael Aldred joined the British home electronics maker Dyson two decades ago, he had a simple goal: to quickly build a robotic vacuum cleaner.

articles.headline: Trump Plans Have Deal Makers Dreaming Big ($100-Billion-Cash-Takeover Big)
articles.snippet: At an annual conference at Tulane University, lawyers, bankers and even activist investors agreed that mergers and acquisitions should boom to new levels under President Trump.
articles.abstract: At an annual conference at Tulane University, lawyers, bankers and even activist investors agreed that mergers and acquisitions should boom to new levels under President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — It wasn’t just cocktails on Bourbon Street or lucky breaks at the blackjack tables that contributed to the buoyant mood of the deal makers who gathered here last week. President Trump — and his support for lower taxes and lighter regulations — also had something to do with it.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Trump Aides’ Disclosures Reveal Surge in Lucrative Political Work
articles.snippet: As cash has flooded Washington from a variety of groups, even the anti-establishment activists and operatives who sided with President Trump have been enriched.
articles.abstract: As cash has flooded Washington from a variety of groups, even the anti-establishment activists and operatives who sided with President Trump have been enriched.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald F. McGahn II, now President Trump’s White House counsel, made $2.4 million as a lawyer with a client list loaded with deep-pocketed conservative groups, from Americans for Prosperity, backed by the conservative billionaires Charles G. and David H. Koch, to the Citizens United Foundation.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder, Eric Lipton and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Google Training Ad Placement Computers to Be Offended
articles.snippet: It’s about context. Google engineers are trying to teach machines to recognize what can be offensive or inoffensive depending on the situation.
articles.abstract: It’s about context. Google engineers are trying to teach machines to recognize what can be offensive or inoffensive depending on the situation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Over the years, Google trained computer systems to keep copyrighted content and pornography off its YouTube service. But after seeing ads from Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble and Wal-Mart appear next to racist, anti-Semitic or terrorist videos, its engineers realized their computer models had a blind spot: They did not understand context.

articles.headline: It’s Not Their Pop Idol, but a Bot. Fans Cheer Anyway.
articles.snippet: Chatbots on Facebook Messenger are changing how the music industry connects with listeners, who say they’re happy to hear even from automated versions of their favorite stars.
articles.abstract: Chatbots on Facebook Messenger are changing how the music industry connects with listeners, who say they’re happy to hear even from automated versions of their favorite stars.
articles.lead_paragraph: In January, Christina Ausset, a 24-year-old Maroon 5 fan in France, spotted an enticing Twitter post from another of the band’s followers: “I just had a conversation with Maroon 5! Awesome!”

articles.headline: An Idaho Town Bucks the Perception of Rural Struggle
articles.snippet: New manufacturing jobs and population growth have lifted Twin Falls, where the image of rural America painted in the presidential campaign is far from reality.
articles.abstract: New manufacturing jobs and population growth have lifted Twin Falls, where the image of rural America painted in the presidential campaign is far from reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: TWIN FALLS, Idaho — Lost jobs, empty storefronts and shrinking populations. It’s an image of rural America ingrained in many people’s minds, and one that was often reinforced in the election.

articles.headline: Within Hours, Plans for a Quiet Corner of China Send Home Prices Soaring
articles.snippet: China’s effort to create a gleaming metropolis called Xiongan sets off a buying frenzy and shows the unpredictability of its vast property market.
articles.abstract: China’s effort to create a gleaming metropolis called Xiongan sets off a buying frenzy and shows the unpredictability of its vast property market.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — A residential and industrial area roughly 80 miles south of Beijing once barely registered on China’s economic map. Consisting mostly of apartment buildings, villages, wetlands and empty fields, it has primarily been known for its donkey burgers.
